news.Title: Silicon Motion Technology Corporation (SIMO) is Attracting Investor Attention: Here is What You Should Know
news.Content:
Silicon Motion Technology Corporation (SIMO) is Attracting Investor Attention: Here is What You Should Know

Zacks Equity Research
December 17, 2025 5 min read

In this article: SIMO

^GSPC

Silicon Motion (SIMO) has recently been on Zacks.com's list of the most searched stocks. Therefore, you might want to consider some of the key factors that could influence the stock's performance in the near future.
Over the past month, shares of this chip company have returned +1.1%, compared to the Zacks S&P 500 composite's +1% change. During this period, the Zacks Computer - Integrated Systems industry, which Silicon Motion falls in, has lost 6.6%. The key question now is: What could be the stock's future direction?

Although media reports or rumors about a significant change in a company's business prospects usually cause its stock to trend and lead to an immediate price change, there are always certain fundamental factors that ultimately drive the buy-and-hold decision.
Revisions to Earnings Estimates Rather than focusing on anything else, we at Zacks prioritize evaluating the change in a company's earnings projection. This is because we believe the fair value for its stock is determined by the present value of its future stream of earnings.
We essentially look at how sell-side analysts covering the stock are revising their earnings estimates to reflect the impact of the latest business trends. And if earnings estimates go up for a company, the fair value for its stock goes up. A higher fair value than the current market price drives investors' interest in buying the stock, leading to its price moving higher. This is why empirical research shows a strong correlation between trends in earnings estimate revisions and near-term stock price movements.

Silicon Motion is expected to post earnings of $1.31 per share for the current quarter, representing a year-over-year change of +44%. Over the last 30 days, the Zacks Consensus Estimate remained unchanged.
For the current fiscal year, the consensus earnings estimate of $3.55 points to a change of +3.5% from the prior year. Over the last 30 days, this estimate has remained unchanged.
For the next fiscal year, the consensus earnings estimate of $4.88 indicates a change of +37.5% from what Silicon Motion is expected to report a year ago. Over the past month, the estimate has remained unchanged.
With an impressive externally audited track record, our proprietary stock rating tool -- the Zacks Rank -- is a more conclusive indicator of a stock's near-term price performance, as it effectively harnesses the power of earnings estimate revisions. The size of the recent change in the consensus estimate, along with three other factors related to earnings estimates, has resulted in a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) for Silicon Motion.

Lire la suite
The chart below shows the evolution of the company's forward 12-month consensus EPS estimate:
12 Month EPS Projected Revenue Growth While earnings growth is arguably the most superior indicator of a company's financial health, nothing happens as such if a business isn't able to grow its revenues. After all, it's nearly impossible for a company to increase its earnings for an extended period without increasing its revenues. So, it's important to know a company's potential revenue growth.

In the case of Silicon Motion, the consensus sales estimate of $260.55 million for the current quarter points to a year-over-year change of +36.3%. The $863.29 million and $1.05 billion estimates for the current and next fiscal years indicate changes of +7.4% and +21.2%, respectively.
Last Reported Results and Surprise History Silicon Motion reported revenues of $242 million in the last reported quarter, representing a year-over-year change of +13.9%. EPS of $1 for the same period compares with $0.92 a year ago.
Compared to the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $225.07 million, the reported revenues represent a surprise of +7.52%. The EPS surprise was +23.46%.

The company beat consensus EPS estimates in each of the trailing four quarters. The company topped consensus revenue estimates three times over this period.
Valuation No investment decision can be efficient without considering a stock's valuation. Whether a stock's current price rightly reflects the intrinsic value of the underlying business and the company's growth prospects is an essential determinant of its future price performance.
Comparing the current value of a company's valuation multiples, such as its price-to-earnings (P/E), price-to-sales (P/S), and price-to-cash flow (P/CF), to its own historical values helps ascertain whether its stock is fairly valued, overvalued, or undervalued, whereas comparing the company relative to its peers on these parameters gives a good sense of how reasonable its stock price is.

The Zacks Value Style Score (part of the Zacks Style Scores system), which pays close attention to both traditional and unconventional valuation metrics to grade stocks from A to F (an A is better than a B; a B is better than a C; and so on), is pretty helpful in identifying whether a stock is overvalued, rightly valued, or temporarily undervalued.
Silicon Motion is graded C on this front, indicating that it is trading at par with its peers. Click here to see the values of some of the valuation metrics that have driven this grade.
Conclusion The facts discussed here and much other information on Zacks.com might help determine whether or not it's worthwhile paying attention to the market buzz about Silicon Motion. However, its Zacks Rank #3 does suggest that it may perform in line with the broader market in the near term.

news.Title: How Is Skyworks Solutions' Stock Performance Compared to Other Semiconductor Stocks?
news.Content:
How Is Skyworks Solutions' Stock Performance Compared to Other Semiconductor Stocks?

Aditya Sarawgi
December 17, 2025 2 min read

In this article: SWKS

Irvine, California-based Skyworks Solutions, Inc. (SWKS) designs, manufactures, and markets a broad range of high-performance analog and mixed signal semiconductors that enable wireless connectivity. With a market cap of $9.8 billion, the company‚Äôs operations span the US, Indo-Pacific, and EMEA region.

Companies worth between $2 billion and $10 billion are generally described as "mid-cap stocks." SWKS fits right into that category, with its market cap exceeding this threshold, reflecting its substantial size and influence in the semiconductor industry.
More News from Barchart While AI Panic Struck Applied Digital (APLD) Stock, the Smart Money Has a Different View
JPMorgan Says to Sell NVDA March $160 Puts. Should You Actually?
Should You Buy Micron Stock Before December 17? This Analyst Thinks So.
Tired of missing midday reversals? The FREE Barchart Brief newsletter keeps you in the know. Sign up now!
Skyworks touched its 52-week high of $95.46 on Jan. 21 and is currently trading 30.8% below that peak. Meanwhile, SWKS stock has declined 11.1% over the past three months, notably lagging behind the iShares Semiconductor ETF‚Äôs (SOXX) 14.6% surge during the same time frame.
Skyworks‚Äô performance has remained grim over the longer term as well. SWKS stock has plunged 25.6% on a YTD basis and 27.3% over the past 52 weeks, significantly underperforming SOXX‚Äôs 37.5% surge in 2025 and 30.2% returns over the past year.
SWKS stock has traded mostly below its 200-day moving average over the past year, with some notable fluctuations and consistently below its 50-day moving average since early November, underscoring its bearish trend.
Skyworks Solutions‚Äô stock prices gained more than 2% in the trading session following the release of its impressive Q4 results on Nov. 4. During the quarter, the company secured 5G content across premium Android smartphones, including Google Pixel 10, Samsung Galaxy S25, and others. Further, it also expanded in-vehicle infotainment programs with BYD, Stellantis, and a leading Korean OEM.

Meanwhile, Skyworks reported a notable 7.3% year-over-year growth in revenues to $1.1 billion, beating the Street‚Äôs expectations by a significant margin. Moreover, SWKS delivered a notable 13.5% increase in adjusted EPS to $1.76, surpassing the consensus estimates by more than 15%.
Nonetheless, Skyworks has also underperformed its peer, Analog Devices, Inc.‚Äôs (ADI) 31% surge in 2025 and 28.7% returns over the past 52 weeks.
Among the 25 analysts covering the SWKS stock, the consensus rating is a ‚ÄúHold.‚Äù Its mean price target of $84.56 suggests a 28.1% upside potential from current price levels.
On the date of publication, Aditya Sarawgi did not have (either directly or indirectly) positions in any of the securities mentioned in this article. All information and data in this article is solely for informational purposes. This article was originally published on Barchart.com

news.Title: Does Qorvo‚Äôs 2025 Rebound and 28.2% Surge Justify Its Current Valuation?
news.Content:
Does Qorvo‚Äôs 2025 Rebound and 28.2% Surge Justify Its Current Valuation?

Simply Wall St
December 12, 2025 4 min read

In this article: QRVO

Wondering if Qorvo at around $89 is quietly becoming a value play or still a risky semiconductor bet? This breakdown is designed to help you decide without the jargon.
The stock is up 0.5% over the last week, 3.3% over the past month, and 28.2% year to date, but those gains still sit against a 5 year return of about -44.0%.
Recently, Qorvo has stayed in the spotlight as investors focus on the long term demand for radio frequency chips in smartphones, 5G infrastructure, and connected devices. In addition, ongoing attention on reshoring and semiconductor supply chains continues to shape how the market prices companies like Qorvo.
Despite all that interest, Qorvo only scores 1/6 on our valuation checks . We will walk through what different valuation methods are actually saying about the stock, then finish with a more holistic way to think about its real worth.

Qorvo scores just 1/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown .
Approach 1: Qorvo Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a business is worth today by projecting the cash it could generate in the future, then discounting those cash flows back to the present.
For Qorvo, the model starts with last twelve months free cash flow of about $539 million. Analysts provide detailed forecasts for the next few years, and beyond that, Simply Wall St extrapolates further out to build a 2 stage Free Cash Flow to Equity model. Under these assumptions, Qorvo‚Äôs free cash flow is projected to rise to around $730 million by 2035, still in dollar terms.

When all those future cash flows are discounted back to today, the intrinsic value is estimated at roughly $74.31 per share. With the stock trading near $89, the DCF output implies Qorvo is about 20.3% overvalued on this cash flow outlook.
Result: OVERVALUED
Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Qorvo may be overvalued by 20.3%. Discover 903 undervalued stocks or create your own screener to find better value opportunities.
Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Qorvo.
Approach 2: Qorvo Price vs Earnings For profitable companies like Qorvo, the price to earnings (PE) ratio is a useful shorthand for how much investors are willing to pay for each dollar of current earnings. In general, faster earnings growth and lower perceived risk justify a higher PE, while slower growth or higher uncertainty tend to pull that multiple down.

Qorvo currently trades on a PE of about 38.0x, which is roughly in line with the broader Semiconductor industry average of around 38.0x, but above the peer group average near 34.5x. To go a step further, Simply Wall St calculates a proprietary Fair Ratio of 29.1x for Qorvo, which represents the PE you might expect given its specific mix of earnings growth, margins, industry positioning, market cap and risk profile.

Leer m√°s
This Fair Ratio is more tailored than a simple comparison with peers or sector averages because it adjusts for Qorvo‚Äôs own fundamentals rather than assuming it deserves the same multiple as every other chip company. With the shares at 38.0x versus a Fair Ratio of 29.1x, the multiple based view suggests Qorvo is trading at a premium to what its fundamentals currently justify.
Result: OVERVALUED
PE ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Discover 1447 companies where insiders are betting big on explosive growth .
Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Qorvo Narrative Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation, so let us introduce you to Narratives. This is a simple framework on Simply Wall St‚Äôs Community page that lets you tell the story behind your numbers by linking your view of Qorvo‚Äôs future revenue, earnings and margins to a financial forecast, a fair value estimate and a clear buy or sell signal. That fair value is compared to today‚Äôs price and then dynamically updated when new information, like merger news or earnings, comes in. For example, a bullish investor might build a Narrative that leans into 5G, 6G and merger synergies to justify a fair value closer to the high end of recent targets near $128. A more cautious investor could emphasize customer concentration, regulatory risk and handset cyclicality to land nearer the low end around $70. Both perspectives can coexist on the platform as approachable, side by side stories that may make it easier to decide whether Qorvo at about $89 appears attractively priced, fully valued, or too expensive for a given personal outlook.
Do you think there's more to the story for Qorvo? Head over to our Community to see what others are saying!

news.Title: Are You Looking for a Top Momentum Pick? Why Cirrus Logic (CRUS) is a Great Choice
news.Content:
Are You Looking for a Top Momentum Pick? Why Cirrus Logic (CRUS) is a Great Choice

Zacks Equity Research
December 10, 2025 4 min read

In this article: CRUS

Momentum investing is all about the idea of following a stock's recent trend, which can be in either direction. In the "long context," investors will essentially be "buying high, but hoping to sell even higher." And for investors following this methodology, taking advantage of trends in a stock's price is key; once a stock establishes a course, it is more than likely to continue moving in that direction. The goal is that once a stock heads down a fixed path, it will lead to timely and profitable trades.

While many investors like to look for momentum in stocks, this can be very tough to define. There is a lot of debate surrounding which metrics are the best to focus on and which are poor quality indicators of future performance. The Zacks Momentum Style Score, part of the Zacks Style Scores, helps address this issue for us.
Below, we take a look at Cirrus Logic (CRUS) , which currently has a Momentum Style Score of B. We also discuss some of the main drivers of the Momentum Style Score, like price change and earnings estimate revisions.
It's also important to note that Style Scores work as a complement to the Zacks Rank, our stock rating system that has an impressive track record of outperformance. Cirrus Logic currently has a Zacks Rank of #1 (Strong Buy). Our research shows that stocks rated Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) and #2 (Buy) and Style Scores of "A or B" outperform the market over the following one-month period.

You can see the current list of Zacks #1 Rank Stocks here >>>
Set to Beat the Market? Let's discuss some of the components of the Momentum Style Score for CRUS that show why this chipmaker shows promise as a solid momentum pick.
Looking at a stock's short-term price activity is a great way to gauge if it has momentum, since this can reflect both the current interest in a stock and if buyers or sellers have the upper hand at the moment. It's also helpful to compare a security to its industry; this can show investors the best companies in a particular area.

For CRUS, shares are up 2.89% over the past week while the Zacks Electronics - Semiconductors industry is up 4.96% over the same time period. Shares are looking quite well from a longer time frame too, as the monthly price change of 4.11% compares favorably with the industry's 4.17% performance as well.
While any stock can see its price increase, it takes a real winner to consistently beat the market. That is why looking at longer term price metrics -- such as performance over the past three months or year -- can be useful as well. Shares of Cirrus Logic have increased 5.57% over the past quarter, and have gained 18.64% in the last year. In comparison, the S&P 500 has only moved 5.34% and 14.25%, respectively.

Story Continues
Investors should also pay attention to CRUS's average 20-day trading volume. Volume is a useful item in many ways, and the 20-day average establishes a good price-to-volume baseline; a rising stock with above average volume is generally a bullish sign, whereas a declining stock on above average volume is typically bearish. CRUS is currently averaging 478,999 shares for the last 20 days.

Earnings Outlook The Zacks Momentum Style Score also takes into account trends in estimate revisions, in addition to price changes. Please note that estimate revision trends remain at the core of Zacks Rank as well. A nice path here can help show promise, and we have recently been seeing that with CRUS.
Over the past two months, 3 earnings estimates moved higher compared to none lower for the full year. These revisions helped boost CRUS's consensus estimate, increasing from $7.07 to $7.73 in the past 60 days. Looking at the next fiscal year, 3 estimates have moved upwards while there have been no downward revisions in the same time period.

Bottom Line Given these factors, it shouldn't be surprising that CRUS is a #1 (Strong Buy) stock and boasts a Momentum Score of B. If you're looking for a fresh pick that's set to soar in the near-term, make sure to keep Cirrus Logic on your short list.

news.Title: Is It Too Late To Consider Tower Semiconductor After Its 140% 2025 Rally?
news.Content:
Is It Too Late To Consider Tower Semiconductor After Its 140% 2025 Rally?

Simply Wall St
December 9, 2025 5 min read

In this article: TSEM

If you are wondering whether Tower Semiconductor is still a smart buy after such a huge run up in its share price, or if you might be late to the party, this article will break down what the current valuation is actually telling us.
The stock has surged recently, climbing 6.5% over the last week, 47.5% over the past month, and an eye catching 140.5% year to date, while delivering a 384.0% gain over 5 years.
Those moves have been driven by growing investor enthusiasm around analog and specialty semiconductor demand, as well as Tower's strategic positioning as a foundry partner for companies that want alternatives to the largest chip manufacturers. At the same time, shifting expectations about industry consolidation and long term chip demand cycles have added a layer of both excitement and volatility to the story.
Despite that performance, Tower Semiconductor currently scores just 0/6 on our undervaluation checks. In this article we will walk through what different valuation approaches say about the stock today, and then wrap up by looking at a more holistic way to think about its overall worth.

Tower Semiconductor scores just 0/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown .
Approach 1: Tower Semiconductor Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a business is worth by projecting its future cash flows and then discounting those back into today‚Äôs dollars using a required rate of return.
For Tower Semiconductor, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The company is currently generating negative free cash flow of about $25.1 Million, but analysts and extrapolations see this swinging to positive territory and then scaling materially. Projections point to free cash flow reaching roughly $34.3 Million in 2026 and climbing to about $1.43 Billion by 2035, all in $ terms. Simply Wall St only uses direct analyst estimates for the early years, then extrapolates further growth based on recent trends.

After discounting this stream of future cash flows, the DCF model arrives at an intrinsic value of around $63.19 per share. Compared with the current share price, this implies the stock is about 96.2% overvalued.
Result: OVERVALUED
Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Tower Semiconductor may be overvalued by 96.2%. Discover 903 undervalued stocks or create your own screener to find better value opportunities.
Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Tower Semiconductor.

Story Continues
Approach 2: Tower Semiconductor Price vs Earnings For a profitable business like Tower Semiconductor, the price to earnings (PE) ratio is a useful way to see how much investors are willing to pay today for each dollar of current earnings. It ties directly to what the company is actually making now, which makes it more intuitive than cash flow models for many investors.

What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù PE depends on how quickly earnings are expected to grow and how risky those earnings are. Higher growth and lower perceived risk usually justify a higher multiple, while slower growth or higher uncertainty tend to hold the PE down.
Tower currently trades on a PE of 71.2x, which is well above both the Semiconductor industry average of 38.0x and the average of its peers at 44.5x. Simply Wall St also calculates a proprietary ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù of 45.6x, which is the PE you might expect once you factor in Tower‚Äôs specific mix of earnings growth, profitability, industry, market cap and risk profile. Because this Fair Ratio is tailored to Tower, it is more informative than a simple comparison with peers or the broad industry.
With the current PE of 71.2x sitting materially above the 45.6x Fair Ratio, the shares look expensive on this metric.
Result: OVERVALUED
PE ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Discover 1450 companies where insiders are betting big on explosive growth .
Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Tower Semiconductor Narrative Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. Let us introduce you to Narratives, a simple framework on Simply Wall St‚Äôs Community page that lets you turn your view of a company into a story tied to a financial forecast and a fair value. You can compare that fair value with the current price and decide when to buy or sell. You can also track how it updates automatically as new news or earnings arrive, and even see how different investors can look at the same Tower Semiconductor data and reach very different conclusions. For example, one Narrative might lean bullish, assuming accelerating RF Infrastructure and Silicon Photonics growth that justifies a fair value closer to $124 or even $135. A more cautious Narrative might focus on capital intensity, execution and concentration risks and land nearer the low $59 to $60 range. Both perspectives use the same building blocks of future revenues, margins and multiples, just arranged into different, clearly explained stories behind the numbers.
Do you think there's more to the story for Tower Semiconductor? Head over to our Community to see what others are saying!

news.Content:
Tower Semiconductor (NasdaqGS:TSEM): Reassessing Valuation After a 140% Year-to-Date Share Price Surge

Simply Wall St
December 9, 2025 2 min read

In this article: TSEM

Tower Semiconductor (TSEM) has been on a tear lately, with the stock up roughly 48% over the past month and about 83% in the past 3 months, easily outpacing broader chip peers.
See our latest analysis for Tower Semiconductor.
Zooming out, Tower Semiconductor‚Äôs 140.5% year to date share price return and 150.3% one year total shareholder return show that the latest jump to roughly $124 is part of a sustained momentum shift as investors reprice its growth prospects.

If Tower‚Äôs surge has you rethinking what is possible in the chip space, it might be a good moment to explore other high growth tech and AI stocks that could be setting up for the next leg higher.
With shares sitting exactly at Wall Street‚Äôs price target and intrinsic models flashing rich, the rally raises a sharper question: Is Tower still an underappreciated compounder, or has the market already baked in the next wave of growth?
Most Popular Narrative Narrative: 0% Overvalued With Tower Semiconductor‚Äôs last close matching the $124 fair value in the most popular narrative, the spotlight shifts to whether its future earnings runway truly supports that kind of pricing power.
Read the complete narrative.
Curious how a specialty foundry earns a premium price tag, yet still leans on aggressive revenue growth, fatter margins, and a future earnings multiple more often reserved for blue chip leaders? The full narrative unpacks the bold forecasts behind that fair value and why 2027 could be a turning point for Tower‚Äôs earnings mix.

Result: Fair Value of $124 (ABOUT RIGHT)
Have a read of the narrative in full and understand what's behind the forecasts.
However, execution missteps on Tower‚Äôs heavy CapEx buildout, or a faster than expected shift in optical transceiver technologies, could quickly challenge today‚Äôs optimistic assumptions.

news.Title: Cirrus Logic Introduces New Family of Advanced Closed-Loop Haptic Drivers for Next-Generation Automotive Interfaces
news.Content:
This is a paid press release. Contact the press release distributor directly with any inquiries.

Cirrus Logic Introduces New Family of Advanced Closed-Loop Haptic Drivers for Next-Generation Automotive Interfaces

Business Wire
December 9, 2025 4 min read

In this article: CRUS

Automotive-qualified solutions for more intuitive, immersive in-vehicle experiences
AUSTIN, Texas, December 09, 2025 --( BUSINESS WIRE )-- Cirrus Logic (NASDAQ: CRUS), a leading provider of high-performance audio and mixed-signal semiconductor solutions, today announced the launch of its new family of closed-loop haptic drivers CS40L51, CS40L52 and CS40L53, marking the company‚Äôs first haptic driver solutions reliability qualified in accordance with the AEC-Q100 automotive standard. The new family of products brings Cirrus Logic‚Äôs proven expertise in consumer and smartphone haptics to the automotive space, enabling a more consistent, immersive and intuitive tactile user experience across a wide range of in-cabin interfaces.

As automakers look to elevate and differentiate vehicles with personalized, immersive experiences, haptics-enabled smart surfaces play a critical role in enabling premium interior designs that are sleek, modern and sustainable. Cirrus Logic‚Äôs closed-loop technology improves actuator response, creates a wider range of haptics effects and delivers consistent performance across varying conditions. This ensures high-definition haptic feedback on interactive displays, steering wheels, smart surfaces, center consoles, smart seats and more.
"Consumers expect a high level of responsiveness from haptics experiences. Early adoption of haptics in vehicles was not intuitive or consistently reliable, and didn‚Äôt deliver a realistic tactile experience," said Vlad Bulavsky, Director, Automotive Solutions, Cirrus Logic. "Cirrus Logic‚Äôs new low latency, closed-loop haptics technology addresses this challenge for automotive designers who are redefining how we interact with our cars and take user experience to the next level."

"As screens replace physical controls in vehicles, the industry has recognized the need for sophisticated tactile feedback to bridge the gap," said Peter Cooney, Chief Technology Analyst at DATAportl, a leading market research provider. "We are moving past basic vibration to advanced, high-definition haptics that simulate physical textures and clicks. This shift is essential for reducing distraction and is the primary force driving the automotive haptics market today."
Cirrus Logic‚Äôs CS40L51/52/53 family offers a range of features satisfying different use cases and budgets. It simplifies the design process for engineers by integrating key components into an efficient solution. The drivers‚Äô advanced closed-loop hardware and algorithm improve the response time of the actuator and expand usable frequency bandwidth to create a wider range of haptic effects. These new haptics solutions support a broader range of tactile effects and enable new and better ways to leverage haptics for automotive user experiences.

Story Continues
CS40L51 ‚Äì Combines advanced Sensor-less Velocity Control (SVC), real-time audio to haptics synchronization (A2H) and active vibration compensation (AVC) for immersive, high-fidelity feedback.
CS40L52 ‚Äì Features the advanced closed-loop control SVC that optimizes the system's haptic performance in real-time by reducing response time, increasing frequency bandwidth and compensating for manufacturing tolerances and temperature variation.

CS40L53 ‚Äì Features the Click Compensation algorithm to enable consistent haptic feedback across systems by adjusting haptic effects based on the actuator manufacturing characteristics.
By leveraging Cirrus Logic‚Äôs deep expertise in signal processing and consumer electronics, the CS40L51/52/53 drivers provide automotive designers with a scalable platform for both current and future generations of haptic-enabled automotive solutions.
Key Benefits
Consistent haptics performance across manufacturing and temperature variation through advance closed-loop algorithms
Wider frequency range of haptics feedback compared to a conventional system enabling new user experiences and textured effects
Intuitive high-definition haptics feedback enabled by the advanced closed-loop algorithm which improves the actuator response time
Haptics tools that simplify waveform design to accelerate development cycles
Reliability qualified in accordance with the AEC Q100 standard to support a wide range of automotive applications

Availability
Engineering samples of CS40L51, CS40L52 and CS40L53 are available now, with mass production expected to begin in December 2025. Additional product details, including data sheets and application materials, are available at www.cirrus.com/automotive-haptics .
About Cirrus Logic
Cirrus Logic is a leading supplier of innovative analog, mixed-signal, and audio DSP solutions that enable compelling user experiences in mobile, consumer, and automotive applications. Headquartered in Austin, Texas, Cirrus Logic develops cutting-edge technologies that connect people with sound and touch in new ways.
For more information, visit www.cirrus.com .

news.Title: Has Cirrus Logic‚Äôs 24.6% 2025 Rally Already Priced In Future Growth?
news.Content:
Has Cirrus Logic‚Äôs 24.6% 2025 Rally Already Priced In Future Growth?

Simply Wall St
December 7, 2025 5 min read

In this article: CRUS

Wondering if Cirrus Logic is still a smart buy at today‚Äôs price, or if most of the upside has already been captured? This breakdown will walk through what the current market is really pricing in.
The stock has quietly climbed to around $123.82, delivering gains of 2.9% over the last week, 4.4% over the past month, and a strong 24.6% year to date. This hints that investors are warming up to its story after a 61.1% rise over three years.
Recently, Cirrus Logic has been in focus for its role as a key audio and signal processing supplier within major consumer devices, with investors watching closely for design wins and product refresh cycles that can drive future unit demand. In addition, the broader semiconductor space has been reassessed as a potential long term growth engine, which has helped underpin sentiment around niche, high margin chip makers like Cirrus.
Despite this, Cirrus Logic only scores 2 out of 6 on our valuation checks, suggesting the market may already be pricing in a fair chunk of good news. We will walk through different valuation approaches next and then finish with a more nuanced way to think about what the stock is truly worth.

Cirrus Logic scores just 2/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown .
Approach 1: Cirrus Logic Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis A discounted cash flow model estimates what a company is worth by projecting the cash it can generate in the future and discounting those dollars back to today. For Cirrus Logic, the model uses a 2 stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, starting from last twelve months free cash flow of about $524.8 million and then applying growth assumptions over time.

Analyst forecasts and extrapolated estimates see free cash flow easing to around $369.8 million in 2026 and then gradually rising, reaching roughly $442.9 million by 2035, all in $. Simply Wall St discounts these projected cash flows to arrive at an intrinsic value of about $92.58 per share.
With the stock trading around $123.82, the DCF suggests Cirrus Logic is roughly 33.7% overvalued on this methodology, implying that a lot of future optimism is already reflected in the price.
Result: OVERVALUED
Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Cirrus Logic may be overvalued by 33.7%. Discover 908 undervalued stocks or create your own screener to find better value opportunities.
Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Cirrus Logic.
Approach 2: Cirrus Logic Price vs Earnings For a profitable, established business like Cirrus Logic, the price to earnings ratio is a practical way to gauge valuation because it directly links what investors pay today to the profits the company is generating right now. In general, faster growth and lower risk can justify a higher PE multiple, while slower growth or more uncertainty typically warrant a lower one.

Story Continues
Cirrus Logic currently trades on a PE of about 16.6x, which sits well below the broader Semiconductor industry average of roughly 38.0x and also beneath a peer group average of about 29.6x. On the surface, that discount might suggest the stock is attractively priced, but simple peer comparisons do not fully reflect Cirrus Logic‚Äôs specific growth outlook, margins, size and risk profile.

To address this, Simply Wall St uses a proprietary Fair Ratio, which estimates what a reasonable PE should be after accounting for factors such as expected earnings growth, profitability, industry characteristics, market cap and company specific risks. For Cirrus Logic, that Fair Ratio is calculated at around 15.5x, only slightly below the current 16.6x. This points to the market valuing the stock a little above its modelled fair level, but not by a wide margin.
Result: OVERVALUED
PE ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Discover 1452 companies where insiders are betting big on explosive growth .
Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Cirrus Logic Narrative Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation, so let us introduce you to Narratives, a simple way to connect your view of Cirrus Logic‚Äôs business to concrete numbers like future revenue, earnings, margins and fair value. A Narrative on Simply Wall St is your story about the company, translated into a financial forecast and then into a fair value that you can directly compare with today‚Äôs share price to inform whether you might buy, hold, or sell. Narratives are easy to use and live inside the Community page on Simply Wall St‚Äôs platform, where millions of investors share and refine their views, and each Narrative automatically updates when new information, such as earnings or major news, is released. For Cirrus Logic, one investor might build a more optimistic Narrative that assumes strong AI driven laptop demand and diversification into automotive could justify a fair value closer to $140, while a more cautious investor might focus on smartphone concentration risks and cyclical demand and arrive at a fair value nearer $90. This provides a clear framework for what you believe and what you are willing to pay.
Do you think there's more to the story for Cirrus Logic? Head over to our Community to see what others are saying!
This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock, and does not take account of your objectives, or your financial situation. We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. Simply Wall St has no position in any stocks mentioned.
Companies discussed in this article include CRUS .
